title: 114_hr3217
content: The "Refueling Assistance Act of 2015" is a study on motor vehicle refueling assistance for qualified individuals with disabilities. The Secretary of Transportation, in consultation with the Attorney General, will conduct a study on motor vehicle refueling assistance for individuals with disabilities. The study will address the adequacy of regulations, gas station practices, and measures to improve assistance. The study will assess measures for gas stations to improve motor vehicle refueling assistance for individuals with disabilities, considering cost, feasibility, and location factors. It will also explore the feasibility of requiring gas stations to install a calling device for qualified individuals with disabilities. The study will assess the installation of a calling device at gas stations for individuals with disabilities to request motor vehicle refueling assistance in a safe and convenient manner, following accessibility guidelines. The need for appropriate signage at gas stations to clearly identify calling devices for motor vehicle refueling assistance, the cost burden on gas stations to install and maintain these devices, and funding opportunities to offset installation costs. The Secretary will consult with various groups to study methods of disseminating information on motor vehicle refueling assistance, including using technology to locate gas stations with calling devices. The Secretary, in consultation with the Attorney General, will submit a report to Congress summarizing the study results and recommending feasible requirements for gas stations to improve motor vehicle refueling assistance for individuals with disabilities. Regulations to enhance refueling assistance will be promulgated within 180 days, considering the study's outcomes. The Secretary may impose civil penalties on individuals who knowingly violate regulations, considering severity of violation and business size. Penalties should not jeopardize the financial viability of the business. Individuals can be penalized for violating regulations under section 4, but penalties only apply if the violation continues for more than 30 days after receiving notice. SEC. 6. QUALIFIED INDIVIDUAL WITH A DISABILITY DEFINED as per the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990.
